artist: Designer: E. W. (Edward William) Godwin; Maker: Wm (William) Watt Artistic Furniture Warehouse
creditline: The Ulrich Acquisition Fund for Modern Design
description: tall, square-section uprights with tapering cylindrical finials; wedge-shaped back cushion at center of back; upholstered in black
markings: \'[top 1/3 missing] HEIRLOOM/[drawing of spider web]/10&12 GRAFTON STREET/GOWER ST/LONDON, W.C.\', on enamel-covered copper label, on PR side seat rail
text: This chair is termed “Greek” because its legs recall those on Greek furniture, which Godwin sketched from classical marble sculptures in the British Museum. The overall angularity and lack of ornament were an inspiration to the modern design movement of the late 1800s. Though Godwin was not alone in introducing the slant back, his dramatic chair is a link to later designers like Frank Lloyd Wright.
title: Greek-style side chair
